definition: A decentralized digital ledger that records transactions across many computers in a secure, transparent way.
The first and largest cryptocurrency by market cap, created in 2009 by Satoshi Nakamoto.
A blockchain platform that enables smart contracts and decentralized applications (dApps).
An event in Bitcoin where the block reward for miners is cut in half, occurring approximately every 4 years.
Decentralized Finance — financial services like lending, trading, and saving built on blockchains without banks.
The fee paid to process transactions or execute smart contracts on Ethereum and other blockchains.
A digital tool that stores your public and private keys to send, receive, and manage crypto assets.
Fear, Uncertainty, and Doubt — negative sentiment spread to manipulate markets or cause panic.
An individual or entity that holds a large amount of cryptocurrency and can influence market prices.
All-Time High — the highest price an asset has ever reached.
Any cryptocurrency other than Bitcoin (e.g., Ethereum, Solana, Dogecoin).
Self-executing code on a blockchain that runs when predefined conditions are met.
Non-Fungible Token — a unique digital asset representing ownership of art, collectibles, or real-world items.
Locking up crypto to support a blockchain network and earn rewards, common in Proof-of-Stake systems.
Annual Percentage Yield — the real rate of return earned on staking or lending, including compounding.
How easily an asset can be bought or sold without affecting its price.
Decentralized Exchange — a platform to trade crypto directly from your wallet without a central authority.
Centralized Exchange — a traditional crypto exchange like Binance or Coinbase that holds your funds.
A secret code that gives you access to your cryptocurrency. Never share it!
A cryptographic address derived from your private key; used to receive crypto.
A cryptocurrency created as a joke or meme (e.g., Dogecoin, Shiba Inu), often highly volatile.
The base blockchain protocol (e.g., Bitcoin, Ethereum) that processes and finalizes transactions.
A scaling solution built on top of Layer 1 to increase speed and reduce fees (e.g., Arbitrum, Optimism).
A Layer 2 scaling solution that bundles multiple transactions off-chain and posts them to Layer 1.
Decentralized Autonomous Organization — a community-led entity governed by rules on a blockchain.
Free distribution of crypto tokens to wallet addresses, often to promote a new project.
A radical change to a blockchain’s protocol that creates a permanent split into two chains.
A backward-compatible upgrade to a blockchain that doesn’t split the network.
Slang for holding crypto long-term despite market volatility (originally a typo of 'hold').
Do Your Own Research — a reminder to verify information before investing.
A market condition where prices are rising or expected to rise.
A market condition where prices are falling or expected to fall.
Fear Of Missing Out — the anxiety that drives people to buy during price surges.
Slang for being severely financially damaged in a trade or investment.
A phrase expressing belief that a crypto’s price will skyrocket.
A transaction where fees are paid by a third party or deferred, common in some dApps.
A protocol that moves assets between different blockchains (e.g., from Ethereum to Polygon).
Services that provide real-world data (like price feeds) to smart contracts on blockchains.
A temporary loss experienced by liquidity providers when asset prices change in a pool.
Total Value Locked — the amount of crypto deposited in a DeFi protocol.
A scam where developers abandon a project and steal investors’ funds.
Know Your Customer — identity verification required by centralized exchanges.
Holding your own private keys and controlling your crypto, not relying on exchanges.
A hardware or paper wallet not connected to the internet, used for secure storage.
A software wallet connected to the internet, convenient but less secure.
A cryptocurrency pegged to a stable asset like the US dollar (e.g., USDT, USDC).
Depositing more value than you borrow in DeFi to reduce risk of liquidation.
When a DeFi loan is automatically closed because collateral value dropped too low.
Providing liquidity to DeFi protocols to earn rewards in the form of tokens.
The difference between expected and actual price when executing a trade, common in volatile markets.
Maximal Extractable Value — profit miners or validators can make by reordering transactions.
A Layer 2 scaling solution that uses zero-knowledge proofs to validate transactions off-chain.
A cryptographic method that proves a statement is true without revealing the underlying data.
The vision of a decentralized internet built on blockchain technology and user ownership.
A virtual world where users interact via avatars, often using NFTs and crypto for transactions.
The economic model of a cryptocurrency, including supply, distribution, and utility.
The number of coins currently available and trading in the market.
Total value of a cryptocurrency, calculated as price × circulating supply.
A scheme where a group inflates a coin’s price (pump) then sells off (dump), crashing the price.
To aggressively promote a crypto, often without disclosing ownership.
Someone holding a cryptocurrency that has lost significant value.
When users compete by raising gas fees to get their transactions processed first.
Ethereum Improvement Proposal — a design document for new features or changes to Ethereum.
The method a blockchain uses to agree on the state of the network (e.g., Proof-of-Work, Proof-of-Stake).
A consensus mechanism where miners solve complex puzzles to validate blocks (used by Bitcoin).
A consensus mechanism where validators are chosen based on the amount of crypto they stake.
A participant in a PoS network who proposes and validates blocks in exchange for rewards.
A computer that connects to a blockchain network and helps maintain it by storing and validating data.
A node that stores the entire blockchain history and validates all transactions independently.
A node that relies on full nodes for data, using less storage and bandwidth.
The live, primary blockchain network where real transactions occur (vs. testnet).
A sandbox version of a blockchain used by developers to test apps without real money.
A technical document that explains a crypto project’s purpose, technology, and roadmap.
A project’s planned timeline of features, upgrades, and milestones.
Permanently removing tokens from circulation to reduce supply and potentially increase value.
Creating new tokens or NFTs on a blockchain.
A reserve of tokens locked in a smart contract to facilitate trading on a DEX.
Automated Market Maker — a DEX protocol that uses algorithms and liquidity pools instead of order books.
The property of blockchain data that cannot be altered or deleted once recorded.
The ability of different blockchains to communicate and share data seamlessly.
A token used to pay for transaction fees on a specific blockchain (e.g., ETH on Ethereum).
A tokenized version of a crypto from another blockchain (e.g., WBTC = Bitcoin on Ethereum).
A token whose supply automatically adjusts to maintain a target price.
A DeFi loan that is borrowed and repaid in a single transaction, with no collateral required.
When a trader sees a pending transaction and places their own to profit from the price movement.
An attack where one entity creates multiple fake identities to gain influence over a network.
When a single entity controls more than half of a blockchain’s mining power, allowing them to manipulate it.
A cryptocurrency designed to obscure transaction details (e.g., Monero, Zcash).
Technology that enables interaction between different blockchain networks.
Data or activity that is recorded directly on a blockchain and publicly verifiable.
Activity that happens outside the blockchain but may later be recorded on it.
A token that gives holders voting rights on a protocol’s future development.
A token that provides access to a product or service within a blockchain ecosystem.
A token that represents ownership in an asset (like shares) and is regulated as a security.
A set of rules for creating tokens on a blockchain (e.g., ERC-20 for Ethereum fungible tokens).
An Ethereum standard for non-fungible tokens (NFTs).
An Ethereum standard that supports both fungible and non-fungible tokens in one contract.
